content:
- 4 -
衛生福利部民國107年7月20日 衛部秘字第1072161286號通知單註銷密等
Formal arrangements similar to those which govern the operations of the International Salmonella and Escherichia Centre also exist in regard to the work of the two International Shigella Centres (except, of course, that the word "shigella" takes the place of "salmonella and escherichia" in the relevant texts). The two Shigella Centres co-ordinate their activities so as to avoid overlapping as far as possible, and features of this co-ordination are elaborated in a later section of this account. They agree to "train workers from National Shigella Centres in the identification of shigellae", and this (together with training at the International Salmonella and Escherichia Centre in Copenhagen) is also referred to in more detail below.
ANALYSIS OF THE BASIC FUNCTIONS OF THE INTERNATIONAL CENTRES, AND THEIR FUNCTIONAL RELATIONSHIPS
(a) TO WHO AND TO THE IAMS
The basic purpose of these International Centres should be regarded as two-fold. Firstly, they aim at uniformity and consistency throughout the world in the identification and nomenclature of the micro-organisms concerned. Bacterium A, isolated from an outbreak of food poisoning or dysentery in one country, must be recognized as either the same as or different from Bacterium B, isolated from an outbreak in another country; and if it is the same it must be called by the same name. 2 These taxonomic and nomenclatural aims of the Centres' activities provide a part of the essential basis for the other aspect of its two-fold purpose, namely, to improve our knowledge of the epidemiology of the infections concerned, such information in turn being fundamental towards public-health action against those diseases. When the organism causing an outbreak in the one country has been recognized as identical with that causing an outbreak in the other it then becomes possible to compare the two outbreaks more intelligently, to attribute some of their similarities to the fact that the same causative organism is concerned, and to seek for explanations of any differences between the two outbreaks in some circumstance other than a difference in the two causative organisms. For convenience, these two aspects of the Centres' basic purpose will be referred to in the remainder of this report as (a) taxonomic and (b) epidemiological, the one being intimately associated with the other (the term "epidemiological" to be interpreted in this context in a very wide sense, including aspects that are in fact clinical or pathological).
國史饭 Academia Historica
76
